examples: I'd love to go to America.
We went into the house.
Are you going by train?

go.definition: to move or travel somewhere in order to do something
examples: Let's go for a walk.
We're going camping tomorrow.

go.definition: to disappear or no longer exist
examples: When I turned round the man had gone.

go.definition: to develop in a particular way
go.local_word: проходить, протекать хорошо/плохо и т. д.
examples: My exams went really badly.

go.definition: to continue to be in a particular state
examples: We won't let anyone go hungry.
Did you manage to get the car going?
Her hearing is going, so speak loudly.

go.definition: If two things go, they match each other.
examples: Any colour goes with jeans.
The day went very quickly.

go.definition: to have a particular tune or words
examples: I can't remember how it goes.

go.definition: to make a particular sound or movement
examples: My dog goes like this when he wants some food.
I had a go at catching a fish.
If you think you might like skiing, why don't you give it a go (= try to do it)?
Throw the dice Jane, it's your go.
My mother's always having a go at me about my hair.

go.definition: to try to make something succeed, usually by working hard

report.definition: a description of an event or situation
examples: a police report
an annual report on the economy

report.definition: something teachers write about a child's progress at school for their parents
to describe a recent event or situation, especially on television, radio, or in a newspaper
examples: Jo Smith reports on recent developments.
She reported that the situation had changed dramatically.
A woman outside the shop reported seeing the gun.

report.definition: to tell someone in authority that something has happened, especially an accident or crime
examples: He should have reported the accident immediately.
Have you reported the fault to a technician?

report.definition: to complain about someone's behaviour to someone in authority.
examples: I'm going to report him to the police.
Duncan's been reported for smoking.

drive.definition: to make a car, bus, or train move, and control what it does
examples: She's learning to drive.
He drives a red sports car.

drive.definition: to travel somewhere in a car, or to take someone somewhere in a car
drive.local_word: ехать на машине, везти кого-либо на машине
examples: My friend drove me home last night.

drive.definition: to force someone to leave a place
examples: The supermarket has driven many small shops out of the area.

drive.definition: to make someone feel crazy, annoyed, or excited
examples: That noise is driving me mad.

drive.definition: to make someone have a bad feeling or do something bad
examples: The arguments and violence drove her to leave home.

drive.definition: to push something somewhere by hitting it hard
examples: He drove the nail into the wall with a hammer.

drive.definition: to provide the power or energy that makes someone or something work
examples: She was driven by greed and ambition.
The drive from Boston to New York took 4 hours.

drive.definition: the area of ground that you drive on to get from your house to the road
examples: You can park on the drive.

drive.definition: a part of a computer that can read or store information
examples: a DVD drive
Save your work on the C drive.

drive.definition: a great effort to achieve something
examples: The government started a drive to improve standards in schools.

drive.definition: energy and determination to achieve things
examples: She has drive and ambition.

look.definition: to turn your eyes in the direction of something or someone so that you can see them
examples: Look at the picture on page two.
He was looking out of the window.
I looked around and there she was.

look.definition: to try to find someone or something
examples: I'm looking for my keys.
I've looked everywhere but I can't find my bag.

look.definition: used to describe the appearance of a person or thing
examples: That food looks nice.
You look tired, my love.
Do I look silly in this hat?
He looked like a drug addict.

look.definition: used to say that something is likely to happen
examples: It looks like there'll be three of us.
It looks as if he isn't coming.
I'm looking to start my own business.

look.definition: something you say when you are annoyed and you want people to know that what you are saying is important
examples: Look, I've had enough of your complaints.

look.definition: an act of looking at someone or something
examples: Take a look at these pictures.
You've got your photos back - can I have a look?
I've had a look in the drawer but I can't find your passport.
She had a worried look about her.
She gave me a questioning look.
the new look for the summer

look.definition: the appearance of someone or something
examples: I like the look of that new music programme they're advertising.

look.definition: a person's appearance, especially how attractive they are

feel.definition: to experience an emotion or a physical feeling
examples: You shouldn't feel embarrassed about making a mistake.
I felt a sharp pain in my side when I stood up.
"Are you feeling better?" "Yes, thanks, I feel fine now."

feel.definition: If you describe the way a place, situation, or object feels, you say how it seems to you, or what your experience of it is like.
examples: It felt strange to see him again after so long.
The house feels empty without the children.
This shirt feels tight under my arms.
I feel as if I've known you for ages.

feel.definition: to seem to be similar to a type of person, thing, or situation
examples: My feet feel like blocks of ice.
I felt like a fool when I saw what everyone else was wearing.

feel.definition: to think something or have an opinion
examples: I feel that he's the best person for the job.
Do you feel strongly (= have strong opinions) about it?

feel.definition: to touch something, especially with your hands, in order to examine it
examples: He felt her ankle to see if it was broken.

feel.definition: to want something, or want to do something
examples: I feel like some chocolate.
Jane felt like crying.
You could feel the tension in the room.
I could feel them watching me.

feel.definition: the way that something seems, or feels when you touch it
examples: I love the feel of silk against my skin.
His art has a very modern feel to it.

feel.definition: the ability to do something or use something well
examples: Once you get a feel for it, using the mouse is easy.
Claire has a feel for this kind of work.
Our company employs over 400 people.
People live much longer than they used to.

people.definition: all the ordinary people in a country
examples: The rebels have gained the support of the people.

people.definition: all the people of a race
examples: Europe is made up of many different peoples.

learn.definition: to get knowledge or skill in a new subject or activity
examples: I learned Russian at school.
"Can you drive?" "I'm learning."
She's learned a lot about computers in the last three months.
I'm learning to play the piano.

learn.definition: to make yourself remember a piece of writing by reading or repeating it many times
examples: I don't know how actors learn all those lines.

learn.definition: to start to understand that you must change the way you behave
examples: She'll have to learn that she can't have everything she wants.
The good thing is, he's not afraid to learn from his mistakes.

table.definition: a piece of furniture with four legs, used for eating off, putting things on, etc
examples: the kitchen table

table.definition: to put plates, knives, forks, etc on the table to prepare for a meal
a set of numbers or words written in rows that go across and down the page
examples: The table below shows the results of the experiment.

table.definition: a collection of a particular kind of information in a database
to formally suggest that a particular subject is discussed
to decide to discuss something later
